thread.title: West Scranton, Scranton forfeit football games
thread.title_full: West Scranton, Scranton forfeit football games

author: JOBY FAWCETT / STAFF WRITER
title: West Scranton, Scranton forfeit football games
text:
West Scranton, Scranton forfeit football games BY JOBY FAWCETT / STAFF WRITER Published: October 1, 2015 Sign Up Text Alerts | newsletter 
Despite lengthy efforts to work out a resolution, the Scranton School District teachers strike has claimed a pair of high school football games. 
No. 1 Scranton and No. 8 West Scranton will forfeit their games scheduled for Friday night against No. 5 Valley View and No. 6 Delaware Valley, respectively. 
The games were canceled Thursday afternoon after long hours attempting to reschedule the games to Saturday or beyond. 
“The Scranton School District will not be playing any games this weekend,” John Marichak, associate superintendent of schools, said in a statement. 
The football games are officially listed with the Lackawanna Interscholastic Athletic Association as postponed, LIAA president Pete Jordan said. 
Postponed athletic events can be made up if the administrations from both schools come to an agreement to play at a later date, according to Pennsylvania Interscholastic Athletic Association by-laws. 
However, options for rescheduling football games are limited. 
Valley View, which agreed to accommodate Scranton and move the game to Saturday, has accepted a forfeit, because it was not agreeable to a pair of rescheduling options of playing two games in one week or playing after the regular season concluded, according to interim superintendent Corey Castellani. 
“We did not ask for this,” Castellani said. “And we have to do what is in the best interest of our kids. If there is something that could be worked out, we will listen. We were ready to move the game to Saturday. But we cannot accept the two options that were presented.” 
Delaware Valley has also accepted a forfeit from West Scranton, after agreeing to play either Saturday or Sunday, but would not go into next week, principal Brian Blaum said. 
“Unfortunately, we were forced to come to this decision in the best interest of our kids,” Blaum said. “I know the Scranton School District appreciated our willingness to work with them, but we simply ran out of time.” 
Read The Times-Tribune on Friday for more details.
